titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) Gubernatorial records, Jerry A. Danzig, Series 13
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller Gubernatorial records, Jerry A. Danzig, Series 13 FA360

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-03-26 02:39:59 -0400.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller gubernatorial records, Jerry A. Danzig, Series 13

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Nelson A. Rockefeller served as governor of New York from January 1, 1959, to December 18, 1973. He was the first person elected to four consecutive four-year terms as a state governor.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in three subseries:
Subseries 1 - Executive Chamber, 1964-1965 Subseries 2 - Subject Files, 1964-1971 Subseries 3 - Miscellaneous, 1964-1973

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Jerry A. Danzig was born in New York, New York, in 1913. He graduated from the Horace Mann School for Boys in New York and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from Dartmouth in 1934. He served in a variety of management and executive positions for broadcasting companies in New York City, including radio stations WOR and WINS, and network television stations CBS and NBC. In 1961, Danzig served as a television and radio consultant to the New York Republican City Committee. In 1962, he became Special Assistant to the Governor for Radio and Television, a position he held until 1973. Danzig's responsibilities included the production and distribution of radio and television commercials, or spots, for Rockefeller's gubernatorial and presidential campaigns. In 1973, Rockefeller appointed Danzig to the New York State Commission on Cable Television, on which he served until 1981. Danzig was a partner in Chester Burger & Co., a management consulting firm, from 1976 until 1985, when he became a consultant to the National Executive Service Corps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: NOTE TO RESEARCHERS

This series contains the office files of Jerry A. Danzig They document official activities in the execution of his duties as a member of Nelson A. Rockefeller's staff. The actions, decisions, and exchanges of information or points of view documented here occurred in the course of proposing and implementing policies for the Rockefeller administration, political campaigns, and/or Rockefeller's personal activities. However, unless a document is specifically addressed to or from Rockefeller, or is referred to in a document addressed to him, it should not be assumed he saw the document or was aware of its existence or substance. Furthermore, researchers should bear in mind that staff files may contain documents or drafts addressed to Rockefeller that were never shown to him.
SCOPE AND CONTENT

This series covers the majority of Jerry Danzig's service as Nelson Rockefeller's Special Assistant to the Governor for Radio and Television, from 1964 to 1973. The files consist of Danzig's internal memoranda and correspondence regarding Governor Rockefeller's radio and television appearances; bills and invoices for the production, distribution, and broadcast of television promotions; and budgets and expense accounts for programs. There are also scripts and transcripts of short promotional films on Rockefeller. Additional Danzig material is also located in the New York Office series of the Nelson Rockefeller Gubernatorial Papers (III 15 22.3). While the material in this series is primarily New York State related, the material in the New York Office series deals primarily with the 1964 Presidential Campaign.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Series 22 - New York Office, Subseries 3 - Special Assistant to the Governor for Radio and Television, for additional information on Jerry Danzig and the 1964 Presidential Campaign.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Detailed finding aids for each series of this collection are available:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries covers the eight television programs produced and shown throughout New York State on a variety of issues. The shows usually featured Governor Rockefeller and other state officials discussing a particular topic.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional "Executive Chamber" material can be found in the Gene Wyckoff Files series of the Nelson A. Rockefeller, Gubernatorial Papers (III 15 36).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries covers a broad range of general topics from nearly the entire tenure of Danzig's service as Special Assistant. Of particular note in this subseries are two folders. The first is Folder 48, which contains information on the creation of the New York State Lottery System. Danzig's role in determining the proper boundaries in promoting the lottery on television can be seen. The second folder of note is Folder 41, which contains a transcript of "The Extremists," a political program produced for the 1964 California Republican Presidential Primary. The program was never aired, at Governor Rockefeller's request. This folder also has a copy of an article from a San Francisco newspaper on the program and the effect it might have had on the outcome of the primary, won by Arizona Senator Barry Goldwater, who went on to win the Republican nomination for president in 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries is a melange of materials. Most prominent are the three folders of correspondence on the logistics of Governor Rockefeller's "town meetings." These were a series of open meetings across the state with community leaders and the public of specific New York counties. These community relations efforts were often filmed for local airing. Also featured in this subseries are materials on "The Nelson Rockefeller Story," filmed for the 1964 Presidential campaign.
